a.title: A Message from Our Athletic Director

div.a: A Message from Our Athletic Director

nav.div: Mattituck Cutchogue Union Free School District » News » What's New » COVID-19 Update - April 17, 2020

br.p: As we end week number five of school closures, I want to let you know how appreciative we are of your support for the educational program we are jointly delivering to your children. We recognize most of you did not go to school to be a teacher and for the most part were happy to leave this in our hands. We have heard the past few weeks have been challenging and yet rewarding for some of you. To be honest, most of the comments have been something along the lines of…..”I’m sorry I complained about the teachers, I get it now!” to “This isn’t as easy as I thought it would be, please take them back!” We are eager and willing to take them back as soon as permitted. Unfortunately, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that New York’s stay-at-home measures would continue through Friday, May 15, 2020 in conjunction with six other states in the Northeast. If no other Executive Order is issued, we would reopen schools on Monday, May 18, 2020. During this extended closure, we will continue with our distance learning plans, meals and childcare program for essential emergency personnel.
Listed below are timely updates that are important for families K-12:

All second grade students will receive Chromebooks this Monday, April 20th. Included with the Chromebook is user IDs, passwords and directions for use. Later next week we will be holding virtual meetings to further support families in the use of the device. More information will be forwarded through Dr. Devine. Please be aware the on-line tools are in addition to the hard copy instructional packets that will continue each week. As with all of our devices, Chromebooks have a monitoring system included which filters inappropriate content from being accessed. Furthermore, we also receive daily updates if children are searching for anything that would be an indicator of a social-emotional issue or a dangerous situation. We want to thank OLA of Eastern Long Island, a non-for-profit agency that supports social, economic, cultural, and educational development within Long Island’s East End Latino and Hispanic communities for their generous donation of Chromebooks for many of our children at Cutchogue East. This donation offset the costs needed to support our expansion of on-line learning opportunities.

In order to support our emergency personnel workers as they continue to provide care and services throughout our community, we have collaborated with SCOPE and the Greenport Schools to offer this service. Please see the district website for more information.

Food delivery will continue for those families requesting this service. Please refer to the website for more information. We want to thank our community partners for their continued support. We are so grateful to not only provide lunch, but cereal, and some healthy options for a few dinners each week.

We are a few steps closer to recouping the Southwest funds for the flights. Keep your fingers crossed. For those of you who sent in checks that have been uncashed, please look for them in the mail this week.

We have four more weeks ahead to deliver distance learning. In order to keep students engaged and to be cognizant of screen time, we will be making periodic adjustments to our instructional plan that will include more project-based learning opportunities and STEAM related activities in the next few weeks. For the week of April 20th, we will follow the regular instructional plan posted.

Students will be out of school for nine weeks by May 15th. Many people are concerned about students falling behind. While we are planning for some catch-up/review opportunities in various subjects this summer, I believe students may have actually gained in areas we may have been missing.

ul.li: What if students have more empathy; they have learned to be more understanding of others less fortunate or grateful for time spent with friends and family?
What if they have learned to manage time better; downtime was filled with other activities that might interest them like cooking or engaging in a new hobby or playing with a sibling?
What if they learned to appreciate the simpler things like their own backyard, a family meal or watching an old movie?
What if they learned to spend money more wisely or how to plan for shopping trips and meal preparation?

What if they now recognize and place greater value on other professionals such as public servants, essential workers such as truck drivers, grocers, cashiers, custodians, health care workers and logistics?
What if they recognize what teamwork, collaboration and giving up something for the greater good truly feels like?

br.p: In closing, perhaps, just perhaps our children will not have lost much of anything. In fact, I suggest they have gained. They may be the one who is more resilient, empathetic, resourceful, kinder, collaborative, civic-minded and generous at heart. Collectively, I suggest our children will create a better version of tomorrow.

br.br:
Warm regards,
Jill M. Gierasch
Superintendent of Schools
